;美国演员和山达基教徒 Danny Masterson 被隔离在远离普通人群的地方洛杉矶的私人牢房——曾经被前唱片公司高管 Suge Knight 和前足球运动员 OJ Simpson 等人占据——而他正在等待强奸罪的判决听证会。

;

;That '70s Show and The star警方消息人士告诉娱乐新闻网站 TMZ，并援引此案的高调性质，出于自身安全考虑，兰奇被关押在洛杉矶县男子中央监狱的“行政隔离”。

;

;虽然有在他的牢房里没有电视的情况下，马斯特森将被允许每天有两个小时访问休息室并可以使用电话和电视。据 TMZ 报道，除了可以使用监狱图书馆外，这位演员每周还将有三个小时的娱乐时间。

;

;此前，马斯特森已获得 300 万美元的保释金。

;

;本周早些时候，他因两项强奸罪被判有罪，而陪审团在第三项指控上陷入僵局。判决是在经过漫长的重审后作出的，在此期间，他的所有三名原告都出庭作证，随后陪审团进行了持续一周多的审议。

;

;对马斯特森的指控于 2017 年首次曝光。他很快被解雇来自 Netflix 喜剧《牧场》，此后被排除在 That's 90s Show 之外，该系列的重启使他成名。

;

;That '70s Show 演员 Danny Masterson 被判犯有强奸罪

;

; 2020 年，马斯特森因涉嫌 2001 年至 2003 年间在他位于好莱坞山的家中发生的袭击事件而被捕。他的第一次审判于 10 月开始，经过五个多星期的证词，导致陪审团陷入僵局。

;

;马斯特森长期以来一直保持清白，声称每次遭遇都是双方自愿的。他将于 8 月 4 日再次出庭，并面临长达 30 年的牢狱之灾。

;随着北京在台湾展示军事力量，美国表示将帮助台北获得北约的 Link 22 安全数据系统可在两岸发生冲突时增强台湾的防御能力。

;

;分析人士表示，该系统不仅有助于巩固台湾作为准“主要非北约盟友”的地位”，而且还通过战术数据系统增强了台湾军方与美国及其盟友之间的互操作性。

;

;Link 22 是一种安全的超视距通信能力，可将不同类型的设备互连通过提供整个战斗空间的态势感知，对空中、地面、水下和地面战术数据系统进行整合。

;

;即使在恶劣天气下也能运行，Link 22 – 建于 2000 年代以取代多边安全联盟的 Link 11 – 也可用于在参与合作伙伴的军事单位之间交换战术数据。

;

;台湾国防部一位高级官员在 5 月向立法者证实，作为北约主要成员国的美国将帮助自台湾的战术数据系统可与台湾的战术数据系统互操作Link 22 系统。

;

;他还证实，使用北约的安全系统将使台湾与美军建立直接数据链接。

;

;台湾军方目前使用美国制造的 Link 16互连其美国制造的武器系统的数据链路。

;

;但它不能与其他武器系统互操作，包括台湾法国制造的幻影 2000-5 战斗机及其本土的防御战斗机和导弹平台，每个都有自己的数据链系统。

;

;台湾一直面临来自北京的威胁，北京发誓要将台湾置于大陆控制之下，如有必要，将使用武力。

;

;大多数包括美国在内的国家不承认台湾是一个独立的国家。华盛顿反对任何强行改变现状，并承诺帮助保卫台湾，但没有明确表示是否会派兵。

;

;中国国防部长在台湾问题上的强硬路线“给该地区的信息”

;

;在李明博宣布两天后，北京警告美国不要向台北出售武器并帮助其军队获得 Link 22 的使用权，外交部发言人毛宁称这是“极其错误和危险的举动”，

;

;台湾军事专家表示，Link 22 通过帮助美国为台北提供实时情报和作战行动计划，在与北京的潜在战争中非常重要。

; p>;

;“Link 22 使用高频段和超高频段，可以 [over] 长距离运行，使流量能够跨越视距和超视距范围，”Su Tzu-yun 说，台北政府智库国防与安全研究所高级分析师。

;

;该系统具有自动分组功能，可以完整绘制敌友军和桥梁的位置、道路等重要基础设施。他说，这种态势感知信息可以由多个军事司令部共享。

;

;“有了 Link 22，台湾将能够有效地整合其所有武器系统，包括指挥和控制系统、导弹和其他平台由国家中山科学技术研究所开发，”苏说，他指的是台湾顶级武器制造商。

;

;据苏说，此举将大大提高台湾部队的战斗力。他补充说，如果北约在潜在的两岸冲突中选择帮助台湾，台湾将能够迅速访问该集团的系统。

;

;苏说，美国同意帮助该岛获得该系统代表了增加有利于“巩固台湾的主要非北约盟友地位”。

;

;美国专家参与审查台湾最新模拟解放军进攻的兵棋

;

;台湾安全研究员 Chieh Chung隶属于主要反对党国民党的台北智库国家政策基金会表示，台湾需要 Link 22，因为其目前的系统在某种程度上落后于北京的 XS-3 和 DTS-03 系统。

;

;“Link 22 可以大大加强了我们系统的抗干扰能力，提高了指挥效率，同时提供了更快的通信传输，”他说，他指的是北京通过电子战干扰台湾的无线电通信，以便在战争爆发时瘫痪台湾。

;

;Chieh 指出，Link 22 是北约的独家产品。他说，如果美国同意帮助台湾获得它，其他北约成员国也已经同意该岛使用该系统。

;

;“在某种程度上，这也意味着北约国家越来越多地发现中国大陆Chieh 说。

;

;北约批评北京认为其在印太地区日益强硬。该联盟计划在日本开设联络处，并致力于加强与区域合作伙伴的接触。

;

;自乔治·W·布什政府以来，华盛顿一直将台湾视为一个主要的非北约盟友，以便迅速批准武器转让。但它并没有赋予该岛其他 19 个非北约伙伴所享有的官方地位，包括澳大利亚、新西兰、日本、韩国和菲律宾。

;

;国际科学教授亚历山大·黄杰成新北淡江大学关系与战略研究系的一位教授表示，至少二十年来，台湾一直被描述为非北约盟友。

;

;“然而，关键不在于象征意义，也不在于盟友希望成为哪一类盟友将台湾纳入其中。如果确实提供了 Link 22，就可以确保‘互操作性’是可以想象的，”他说。

;

;北约驻日本办事处有可能进一步纠缠与中国的关系：分析人士

; h3>;

;Huang 认为，该系统对于优化台湾的作战能力非常有用。

;

;台湾国际战略研究会台北智库执行主任 Max Lo 表示，Link 22 可以加强

;

;“台湾至少需要数年时间才能接收并掌握该系统。”如果在我们能够完全控制该系统之前发生战争，台湾会怎么做？”他说。

;

;“另外，台湾通过美国获得该系统后，在互操作过程中，应该由哪一方主导？”

;

;北京拒绝台湾总统候选人的“离奇” ' 希望与习近平共进晚餐

;

;罗指出，五角大楼可能认为台湾反应太慢，而台北可能不想将其主导指挥权让给美国。

;< p>;“也有人担心美国在潜在冲突中向台湾提供援助，”他说。

;

;“随着系统转移到台湾，这是否意味着美国实际上不会派遣部队帮助台湾，通过系统协助指挥台湾行动已经是一种帮助？”

;< p>;“美国是我们最亲密的盟友。从保护人民安全到发展经济，我们都是彼此的首选合作伙伴，”他说。

;周六，英国国王查尔斯在罗马尼亚首都布加勒斯特接受军事荣誉礼遇后访问特兰西瓦尼亚 - 作为穿刺者弗拉德的后裔，国王曾说过这个地区在他的“血液”中 - 据信是布拉姆斯托克 1897 年小说德古拉的灵感来源。

;

;国王经常称赞这里的魅力罗马尼亚中部风景如画的特兰西瓦尼亚，他在那里购买了几座传统房屋并设立了一个遗产基金会。

;

;作为长期的环保倡导者，对自然充满热情，查尔斯称特兰西瓦尼亚“实际上是最后一个未受破坏、未被触及的地方”地区”。

;

;作为他自 5 月 6 日加冕国王以来首次海外访问的一部分，查尔斯前往 Valea Zalanului 村 - 距离 Viscri 小村庄约 100 公里（60 英里），在那里他预计将于周二结束访问。

;

;作为王子，查尔斯国王在四分之一个世纪前的 1998 年首次访问维斯克里。

;

;当地市长办公室的 Dan Spataru表示，他回到该地区受到欢迎是一种“情感姿态”。

;

;但与之前的访问相比，他作为新加冕国王的访问将呈现出“更正式、更正式”的性质安全。

;

;“我们很抱歉，因为之前的气氛比较轻松。现在有点僵硬了，”斯帕塔鲁谈到加强的安全协议时说。

;

;“直到 10 年前，查尔斯都会四处走动，走进村民的院子里，发现，没有人保护他，”说当地旅馆老板亚历山德鲁·托德 (Alexandru Toader)。

;

;“现在他不能再这样做了，因为他每次来都会受到高度宣传，”他补充说。

;

;明星成为英国的焦点加紧加冕庆祝活动

;

;这位 37 岁的老人说，在过去的几周里，作为安全协议的一部分，当局甚至询问了他即将接待的客人。

;

; Charles 于 2016 年在 Viscri 买了他的第一所房子，被该地区的土路、马车和坐落在绿色山丘上的色彩鲜艳的房子所吸引。

;

; Sun, 04 Jun 2023 04:20:01 +0800 Global climate change policy still failing women despite 50 years of meetingshttps://www.scmp.com/comment/opinion/article/3222434/global-climate-change-policy-still-failing-women-despite-50-years-meetings?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.06.04 03:00;
;;

;6 月 5 日是联合国发起的世界环境日 50 周年1972 年 6 月在斯德哥尔摩人类环境会议上。

;

;即使经过 50 年的努力来保护环境，气候变化的影响对女性的影响尤为严重。自 1970 年代以来，热暴露导致的女性死亡率显着增加。从 1970 年代到 2000 年代，自然灾害造成的性别死亡率的不平等现象不断加剧。

;

;例如，1991 年高尔基飓风袭击孟加拉国时，女性死亡人数是男性的 14 倍。在 2004 年的印度在海洋海啸中，女性占所有死亡人数的 70%，在受灾最严重的地区，这一数字上升到 80%。

;

;女性不成比例地面临气候变化的负面后果的原因有很多。例如，她们特别脆弱，因为她们经常需要为家庭提供食物、水和燃料等资源。

;

;联合国估计，全球约有 3.83 亿妇女和女童生活在极端贫困中去年年底。尽管 63% 的 25 至 54 岁女性在全球工作，但据估计她们与男性相比仍面临 23% 的工资差距。

;

;同时，缺乏经济和社会赋权限制了女性参与关于适应和减缓的气候变化决策。据估计，妇女和五岁以下儿童承担着 88% 的气候变化引起的疾病负担。

;

;要应对气候变化，必须承认性别因素并将其纳入政策框架。女性必须站在开发可持续技术的前沿，才能适应不断变化的气候。发展基础设施需要考虑性别平等的更多投资。

;

;针对气候变化采取针对特定性别的方法将有助于提升妇女权利问题并促进性别平等。在农业受到气候变化威胁的时候，它还可以帮助提高产量。根据联合国的一份报告，让女性与男性一样获得农业资源可以将发展中国家女性农场的产量提高 20% 到 30%，从而使农场总产量提高多达 4%。

;

;卢旺达是一个因其致力于促进性别平等而脱颖而出的国家，包括努力适应和减缓气候变化。其国家环境和气候变化政策强调了将性别观点纳入行动的重要性，多个网络作为女性交流知识、分享经验和倡导解决性别问题的气候政策的途径。

;

;同时妇女被认为容易受到气候变化的影响，但她们也是适应和缓解措施的拥护者。在智利，女性正在利用她们在工程、研究和项目管理方面的技能参与可再生能源项目，包括太阳能和风能的开发。他们在倡导家庭和社区的能源效率和节能实践方面发挥着至关重要的作用。

;

;当成员国在 2017 年德国波恩联合国气候变化会议上通过性别行动计划时，他们寻求改善气候政策对性别相关问题的回应。联合国气候机构强调了确保国家适应计划响应妇女需求的必要性，这些机构还加强了提高妇女平等参与气候宣传和行动的举措。

;

;在性别日2021 年在苏格兰格拉斯哥举行的联合国气候变化会议上，女性走上了全球舞台，要求增加代表权。 Even though a day was dedicated to gender issues, and multiple countries made financial pledges, the conference did not feature many women at the decision-making level, particularly indigenous women and those from vulnerable countries. This underrepresentation is concerning as women comprised less than a third of country negotiating teams attending the UN summit in Sharm el-Sheikh, Egypt, last year.

;

;Another striking example of the gender disparity was evident in the group photo of world leaders at last year's summit, where only seven of the 110 leaders present were women. This was one of the lowest concentrations of women at recent UN climate meetings, according to the Women's Environment and Development Organisation, with the gender imbalance extending beyond leaders as some countries' delegations consisted of over 90 per cent men.

;

;One possible measure for the next UN climate change conference, which takes place from November 30 to December 12 in Dubai, is to give greater precedence to the gender action plan.

;

;This will involve encouraging states to create climate policies that consider gender equality and increase the representation of women in decision-making roles at all levels. It is critical to prioritise research on how climate change affects women, to aid in the development of more appropriate policy responses.

;

;If the world's largest climate conference were to focus on the effects of climate change on women and commit to ensuring their meaningful participation, it would have a significant impact on global decision-making while contributing to a just and sustainable future for all. Fifty years should be enough time for the world to implement a gender-sensitive climate agenda.

;;

;A senior US diplomat will visit Beijing next week, the State Department said on Saturday, the latest in a string of meetings as Washington tries to ease tensions with its “strategic competitor” and prevent relations from deteriorating further.

;

;Assistant Secretary of State for East Asian and Pacific Affairs Daniel Kritenbrink will travel to China and New Zealand from June 4-10 to “discuss key issues in the bilateral relationship”, the State Department said in a statement with no further details. He will be accompanied on the China leg by National Security Council Senior Director for China and Taiwan Affairs Sarah Beran.

;

;Kritenbrink's visit follows reports of a secret trip to China by CIA Director William Burns last month and a meeting between US National Security Adviser Jake Sullivan and the director of China's Central Foreign Affairs Commission, Wang Yi, in Austria, also in May, as part of efforts to bolster communication.

;

;And last week, Chinese Commerce Minister Wang Wentao met with US Commerce Secretary Gina Raimondo in Washington before travelling to Michigan to sit down with US Trade Representative Katherine Tai on the margins of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation trade meeting.

;

;But these early signs of bolstered contacts have not extended to the military. Beijing has continued to rebuff US efforts to improve defence ties, a stance that US Defence Secretary Lloyd Austin criticised at the Shangri-La Dialogue in Singapore on Saturday after Chinese Defence Minister General Li Shangfu reportedly refused to meet him on the sidelines.

;

;Beijing's reluctance to talk undermines efforts to maintain peace in a region where the two rivals are increasing their military firepower, Austin said at the conference, Asia's top security summit, which wraps up Sunday.

;

;“For responsible defence leaders, the right time to talk is any time,” Austin said, adding that Washington would not stand for “coercion and bullying” of its partners and allies by China.

;

;Chinese officials in Singapore countered that Austin and other US officials have distorted the facts, are intent on encircling China and are undermining the one-China principle through weapon sales and increased exchanges with Taiwan. Both sides have warned of the growing risk of a military conflict over the self-governing island.

;

;Shangri-La Dialogue: US and China stand ground on Taiwan, South China Sea

;

;Other strains between the world's two largest economies include trade, technology and investment policies, China's human rights record and island building in the South China Sea.

;

;Kritenbrink is expected to arrive Sunday, June 4, the 34th anniversary of China's crackdown on pro-democracy protesters in Tiananmen Square. Secretary of State Antony Blinken noted in a separate statement on Saturday that the US will observe the anniversary.

;

;“The victims' bravery will not be forgotten and continues to inspire advocates for these principles around the world,” Blinken said, adding: “The United States will continue advocating for people's human rights and fundamental freedoms in China and around the world.”

;

;In November, Chinese President Xi Jinping and US President Joe Biden laid out a road map for improving ties through a “step ladder” of visits by senior finance, trade and diplomatic officials, potentially leading to a Xi trip to San Francisco in November for the Apec summit.

;

;US-China relations continue to thaw as trade officials meet in Detroit

;

;Those confidence-building efforts ground to a halt, however, after a Chinese surveillance balloon crossed North America in late January and early February. Washington cancelled Blinken's scheduled February trip to China, and Beijing decried the downing of the balloon, accusing Washington of overreacting. Several lines of communication were cut as a result.

;

;At the Group of 7 meeting in Japan last month, Biden forecast that ties between Washington and Beijing would thaw soon. The White House has said it was trying to arrange visits by Blinken, Raimondo and Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen.

;

;A major focus of Kritenbrink's trip will most likely be a possible Biden visit to China, but Kritenbrink will also fly to Auckland to participate in the US -New Zealand Strategic Dialogue before returning to Washington.

; Sun, 04 Jun 2023 03:20:01 +0800 Joe Biden signs debt ceiling bill that pulls US back from brink of unprecedented defaulthttps://www.scmp.com/news/world/united-states-canada/article/3222871/joe-biden-signs-debt-ceiling-bill-pulls-us-back-brink-unprecedented-default?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.06.04 02:28;

;With just two days to spare, US President Joe Biden signed legislation on Saturday that lifts the nation's debt ceiling, averting an unprecedented default on the federal government's debt.

;

;The White House announced the signing, done in private at the White House, in an emailed statement in which Biden thanked congressional leaders for their partnership.

;

;The Treasury Department had warned that the country would start running short of cash to pay all of its bills on Monday, which would have sent shock waves through the US and global economies.

;

;Republicans refused to raise the country's borrowing limit unless Democrats agreed to cut spending, leading to a stand-off that was not resolved until weeks of intense negotiations between the White House and House Speaker Kevin McCarthy.

;

;The final agreement, passed by the House on Wednesday and the Senate on Thursday, suspends the debt limit until 2025 – after the next presidential election – and restricts government spending. It gives lawmakers budget targets for the next two years in hopes of assuring fiscal stability as the political season heats up.

;

;Raising the nation's debt limit, now at US$31.4 trillion, will ensure that the government can borrow to pay debts already incurred.

;

;“Passing this budget agreement was critical. The stakes could not have been higher,” Biden said from the Oval Office on Friday evening. “Nothing would have been more catastrophic,” he said, than defaulting on the country's debt.

;

;“No one got everything they wanted but the American people got what they needed,” Biden said, highlighting the “compromise and consensus” in the deal. “We averted an economic crisis and an economic collapse.”

;

;Biden hails 'big win' as US debt deal passes Congress, averting default

;

;Biden used the opportunity to itemise the achievements of his first term as he runs for re-election, including support for hi-tech manufacturing, infrastructure investments and financial incentives for fighting climate change. He also highlighted ways he blunted Republican efforts to roll back his agenda and achieve deeper cuts.

;

;“We're cutting spending and bringing deficits down at the same time,” Biden said. “We're protecting important priorities from Social Security to Medicare to Medicaid to veterans to our transformational investments in infrastructure and clean energy.”

;

;Even as he pledged to continue working with Republicans, Biden also drew contrasts with the opposing party, particularly when it comes to raising taxes on the wealthy, something the Democratic president has sought.

;

;It's something he suggested may need to wait until a second term.

;

;“I'm going to be coming back,” he said. “With your help, I'm going to win.”

;

;Biden's remarks were the most detailed comments from the Democratic president on the compromise he and his staff negotiated. He largely remained quiet publicly during the high-stakes talks, a decision that frustrated some members of his party but was intended to give space for both sides to reach a deal and for lawmakers to vote it to his desk.

;

;Biden praised McCarthy and his negotiators for operating in good faith, and all congressional leaders for ensuring swift passage of the legislation. “他们采取了负责任的行动，将国家的利益置于政治之上，”他说。

;

;总的来说，这份长达 99 页的法案限制了未来两年的支出，并改变了一些政策，包括实施新的工作年长的美国人接受食品援助和批准许多民主党人反对的阿巴拉契亚天然气管道的要求。 Some environmental rules were modified to help streamline approvals for infrastructure and energy projects – a move long sought by moderates in Congress.

;

;The Congressional Budget Office estimates it could actually expand total eligibility for federal food aid, with the elimination of work requirements for veterans, homeless people and young people leaving foster care.

;

;US spy chief William Burns made secret visit to China, reports say

;

;The legislation also bolsters funds for defence and veterans, cuts back some new money for the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) and rejects Biden's call to roll back Trump-era tax breaks on corporations and the wealthy to help cover the nation's deficits. But the White House said the IRS' plans to step up enforcement of tax laws for high-income earners and corporations would continue.

;

;The agreement imposes an automatic overall 1 per cent cut to spending programmes if Congress fails to approve its annual spending bills – a measure designed to pressure lawmakers of both parties to reach consensus before the end of the financial year in September.

;

;In both chambers, more Democrats backed the legislation than Republicans, but both parties were critical to its passage. In the Senate the tally was 63-36 including 46 Democrats and independents and 17 Republicans in favour, 31 Republicans along with four Democrats and one independent who caucuses with the Democrats opposed.

;

;The vote in the House was 314-117.
